natural problem: If $a @ b$ is defined as $a @ b$ = $3a - 3b$, what is the value of $3 @ 5$?
natural solution: You should note quickly in your head that $3a - 3b = 3(a-b)$. Then, plugging in $a = 3$ and $b=5$, we get $3(3-5) = 3(-2) = \boxed{-6}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b. a @ b = 3 * a - 3 * b"
shows  "(3 :: real) @ 5 = -6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If $a @ b$ is defined as $a @ b$ = $3a - 3b$, what is the value of $3 @ 5$? The final Answer is -6
 ### Proof
 You should note quickly in your head that $3a - 3b = 3(a-b)$. Then, plugging in $a = 3$ and $b=5$, we get $3(3-5) = 3(-2) = \boxed{-6}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b. a @ b = 3 * a - 3 * b"
shows  "(3 :: real) @ 5 = -6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Define an operation $\odot$ such that $a \odot b = 3a - 3b$. Calculate the result of $3 \odot 5$. The final answer is $-6$.
